snippet: There is one quick lesson to be learned from the break-in of a journalist's Apple iCloud account: segregate your Apple services. That is an option, even though Apple recommends using one universal ID for all Apple services.
abstract: There is one quick lesson to be learned from the break-in of a journalist's Apple iCloud account: segregate your Apple services. That is an option, even though Apple recommends using one universal ID for all Apple services.

headline.main: What You Can Do to Better Protect Your Apple Account

snippet: The disappearance of the app in the upcoming iOS 6 operating system seemed to chill any lingering hints of the warmth that once existed between Apple and Google.
abstract: The disappearance of the app in the upcoming iOS 6 operating system seemed to chill any lingering hints of the warmth that once existed between Apple and Google.

headline.main: Apple to Remove YouTube App From iPhone and iPad
headline.print_headline: Apple Drops YouTube App In Mobile System Update

byline.original: By NICK WINGFIELD and CLAIRE CAIN MILLER

snippet: The break-in over the weekend of the iTunes account of a seasoned technology writer serves as a cautionary tale about how vulnerable people can be to malicious hackers.
abstract: The break-in over the weekend of the iTunes account of a seasoned technology writer serves as a cautionary tale about how vulnerable people can be to malicious hackers.

headline.main: Apple Account Break-In Highlights Security Weakness

snippet: Moving data from a Windows computer to a new Mac is easier than it used to be, thanks to a helping hand from Apple.
abstract: Moving data from a Windows computer to a new Mac is easier than it used to be, thanks to a helping hand from Apple.

headline.main: Q&A: Moving From PC to Mac

snippet: In the last year, the initial public offerings of once obscure security start-ups have outperformed the offerings from household names like Facebook and Zynga.
abstract: Initial public offerings of once obscure computer security start-ups in the last year have outperformed offerings from household names like Facebook and Zynga; big companies are expected to spend $32.8 billion on computer security in 2012, up 9 percent from 2011; rise of security start-ups is fueled by new technology, fear, and wealthy investors.

headline.main: Security Start-Ups Catch Fancy of Investors
headline.print_headline: Security Start-Ups Catch Fancy Of Investors

byline.original: By NICOLE PERLROTH and EVELYN M. RUSLI

snippet: The Capitol Theater in Port Chester, N.Y. — known as a rock stage where acts like the Grateful Dead and Janis Joplin have performed — is set to reopen Sept. 4 after a $2 million renovation by Peter Shapiro.
abstract: Capitol Theater in Port Chester, NY, is set to reopen after a $2 million renovation by Peter Shapiro; theater is known as a rock stage with great acoustics, where acts like the Grateful Dead and Janis Joplin have performed.

headline.main: A Hall Full of Memory Rocks Out Once More
headline.print_headline: A Hall Full Of Memory Rocks Out Once More

snippet: 4:45 p.m. | Updated  Adding background and details, response from  Google . The rift between  Apple  and Google just got a little wider. On Monday, Apple released a test version of its coming iOS 6 operating system, which powers iPads and iPhones,...
abstract: Apple releases a test version of its coming iOS 6 operating system, minus the YouTube app from its lineup of built-in apps; change is noteworthy because Apple has included the YouTube app with iOS since it released the first iPhone in 2007; disappearance seems to chill any remnants of warmth that once existed between Apple and Google, which owns YouTube. (M)

headline.main: Apple Drops YouTube App In Mobile System Update

byline.original: By NICK WINGFIELD and CLAIRE CAIN MILLER

snippet: SAN JOSE, Calif. - Back in the early 1930s, a magician by the name of Horace Goldin went to court to defend his signature illusion: sawing a woman in half.     Mr. Goldin filed a lawsuit against the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company for using this ma...
abstract: Nick Bilton Disruptions column contends Apple, by presenting evidence in a patent lawsuit against Samsung Electronics, is allowing competitors and the public to see inside one of the most secretive companies in the world; holds Apple could risk losing some of its magic by showing how it designs products that twice radically changed the electronics industry. (M)

headline.main: Disruptions: At a Trial, Apple Spills Some Secrets
